questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His family emigrated from Somalia 3 months ago after a severe drought, during which access to food was limited. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pale conjunctivae, swollen tongue, and an erythematous throat and mouth. There is peeling and cracking of the skin at the corners of the mouth. The skin of his head is erythematous and covered with yellow scaling plaques. Cardiopulmonary examination discloses no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.8 g/dL and his mean corpuscular volume is 87 μm3. Erythrocyte glutathione reductase assay shows an increased activity coefficient. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin deficiency (vitamin B12 deficiency) can occur in malnourished children and manifest with glossitis, angular cheilitis, and signs of anemia, such as pale conjunctiva. However, patients with vitamin B12 deficiency have macrocytic rather than normocytic anemia. Moreover, seborrheic dermatitis is not consistent with this deficiency, and other features of vitamin B12 deficiency such as neuropathy would be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid deficiency (vitamin C deficiency) may occur in malnourished individuals and manifest with normocytic anemia. However, infantile vitamin C deficiency commonly manifests with irritability, pseudoparalysis, and gingival hemorrhage, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, follicular hyperkeratosis rather than seborrheic dermatitis is seen. Glossitis, angular cheilitis, and stomatitis are not commonly seen in vitamin C deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Retinol deficiency (vitamin A deficiency) is most commonly seen in resource-limited countries due to malnutrition. However, this deficiency does not typically cause glossitis, cheilitis, seborrheic dermatitis, or angular stomatitis. Instead, vitamin A deficiency manifests with xerosis cutis and ocular features such as night blindness and Bitot spots on examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (vitamin B3 deficiency) can be caused by malnourishment and manifest with glossitis, angular cheilitis, and stomatitis. However, pellagra which is characterized by dermatitis in the C3 and C4 dermatomes, hyperpigmentation of the skin, diarrhea, vomiting, and neurologic symptoms (e.g., anxiety, dementia) is typically seen. Moreover, vitamin B3 deficiency does not typically manifest with anemia.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of riboflavin deficiency (vitamin B2 deficiency), which can develop in individuals who do not (or are unable to) consume dairy products, meat, or eggs. Other conditions that cause riboflavin deficiency include celiac disease and short bowel syndrome (due to malabsorption), malignancies, anorexia, and long-term phenobarbital use. Riboflavin is a precursor for flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which serves as a redox cofactor for various enzymes, including glutathione reductase. Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measuring the activity coefficient of erythrocyte glutathione reductase in the absence and presence of FAD. An increase in activity upon addition of FAD, as seen in this patient, indicates a large amount of unsaturated enzyme due to riboflavin deficiency.
questions.hint: Glossitis, pharyngeal hyperemia, angular cheilitis, stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis of the scalp, and normocytic-normochromic anemia are suggestive of a certain vitamin deficiency. An increased activity coefficient of erythrocyte glutathione reductase confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because of progressive memory loss and weakness over the past 6 months. She is now unable to perform activities of daily living and has had several falls in her apartment. She has diarrhea but has not had nausea or vomiting. She was treated for tuberculosis 10 years ago. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but stopped 8 years ago. She drinks one pint of vodka daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows glossitis and a hyperpigmented rash on her face and arms. There are multiple bruises over both arms. On mental status examination, she is oriented to place and person only. Short-term memory is impaired; she can recall 0 out of 5 objects after 10 minutes. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) deficiency can cause dermatitis and enteritis and is classically associated with distal paresthesias and dysesthesias (burning sensation of the feet). However, vitamin B5 deficiency is rare, and another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of glossitis and dementia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency results in clinical findings collectively known as scurvy, which can include ecchymoses, bleeding gums, and petechiae, none of which is seen in this patient. The primary cause of ascorbic acid deficiency is prolonged dietary deficiency. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's constellation of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

While vitamin B7 (biotin) deficiency can cause dermatitis (around the eyes, nose, and mouth), enteritis, and CNS changes, it is very rare and primarily caused by prior antibiotic use and excessive raw egg ingestion, neither of which is seen here. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's constellation of symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use and result in anterograde amnesia (as in Korsakoff syndrome). However, it usually manifests with features of wet beriberi (high-output cardiac failure), dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy), and/or Wernicke encephalopathy (oculomotor dysfunction, gait ataxia, confusion), none of which are seen here. Other causes of vitamin B1 deficiency include malnutrition, prolonged vomiting and diarrhea, and bariatric surgery. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of glossitis and dermatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

While vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency can cause glossitis, it is also associated with angular cheilitis and stomatitis. Common causes of vitamin B2 deficiency include insufficient intake or absorption (e.g., vegan diet, lactose intolerance). Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of diarrhea and dementia.

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use or tuberculosis (TB) treatment (isoniazid) and result in glossitis and seborrheic dermatitis. However, this patient's TB treatment occurred ∼ 10 years ago and she does not have other features of vitamin B6 deficiency such as cheilitis, stomatitis, and seizures, making another vitamin deficiency more likely. Other causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include malnutrition and chronic kidney and liver disease.

G) CORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency can result in pellagra, a systemic disease that is characterized by glossitis and the 4 Ds: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and possible death. Common causes of pellagra include insufficient niacin intake, chronic alcohol use (as seen here), and conditions caused by tryptophan deficiency such as Hartnup disease (due to decreased renal and intestinal tryptophan absorption) and carcinoid syndrome (due to increased tryptophan metabolism). This patient's presentation is concerning for severe niacin deficiency, and urgent vitamin B3supplementation is indicated to prevent further deterioration.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.
questions.hint: This woman has alcohol use disorder and presents with glossitis, diarrhea, symptoms of dementia (e.g., progressive memory loss), and dermatitis (hyperpigmented rash on sun-exposed areas), making pellagra the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and painful swelling of her right knee for 3 weeks. She works as a professional ballet dancer and says, “I'm always trying to be in shape for my upcoming performances.” She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness and limited range of motion in her right knee. Oral examination shows bleeding and swelling of the gums. There are diffuse petechiae around hair follicles on her abdomen and both thighs. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 35 seconds, and a bleeding time of 11 minutes (N = 2–7). Arthrocentesis of the right knee shows bloody synovial fluid. The patient’s condition is most likely associated with a defect in a reaction that occurs in which of the following cellular structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lysosome is the site at which macromolecules (e.g., misfolded proteins, cell debris) are degraded; it is not involved in collagen synthesis. Defects in lysosome function occur in lysosomal storage diseases, whereas this patient's symptoms are characteristic of scurvy.

B) INCORRECT:

The final modification and packaging of the procollagen triple helix into transport vesicles are the last steps prior to its secretion into the extracellular space (i.e., exocytosis) and take place in the Golgi apparatus. These processes do not require vitamin C.
Image Description:

The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

C) CORRECT:

Hydroxylation of lysine and proline residues in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts is an essential step in collagen synthesis, as hydroxylysine-lysine cross-links between tropocollagen molecules are needed in order to form firm collagen fibrils. This reaction is catalyzed by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase and requires vitamin C as a cofactor. Consequently, vitamin C deficiency, as seen in this patient, reduces the tensile strength of collagen and results in typical manifestations of scurvy, which include bleeding diathesis due to weakened vessel walls (potentially leading to hemarthrosis and mucosal bleeding), delayed wound healing, swollen gums, perifollicular petechiae, a weakened immune response, and fatigue (due to anemia).
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

D) INCORRECT:

The transcription of collagen DNA to mRNA is the first step in collagen synthesis and takes place in the nucleus of fibroblasts. This process is mainly mediated by RNA polymerase II and does not require vitamin C.

E) INCORRECT:

The extracellular space is the site of tropocollagen formation, cross-linking, and collagen fiber formation. Following its secretion into the extracellular space, the procollagen triple helix is cleaved at the C-terminus and N-terminus to form water-insoluble tropocollagen. Adjacent tropocollagen molecules are reinforced through the cross-linking of hydroxylysine residues (catalyzed by copper-dependent lysyl oxidase) to form collagen fibrils. Finally, several collagen fibrils accumulate to form collagen fibers. Vitamin C does not play a role in any of the steps taking place in the extracellular space.

F) INCORRECT:

Free ribosomes float within the cytosol and are the site of synthesis of intracellular proteins (cytosolic, nuclear, and mitochondrial proteins). However, collagen is a secreted protein and is therefore translated by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (site of synthesis of secretory proteins) instead. Vitamin C does not play a role in the translation step of collagen synthesis.
questions.hint: This underweight patient's hemarthrosis, perifollicular petechiae, and bleeding gums are likely due to impaired collagen synthesis secondary to vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) from malnutrition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a pruritic rash on her face and extremities for the last year that increases with sun exposure. Her parents report that she often seems clumsy and has had several falls in the last two weeks. Physical examination shows an erythematous, scaly rash with hyperpigmentation over the nasal bridge and cheeks as well as on the dorsal forearms and hands. Urinalysis shows high levels of neutral amino acids. The most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition includes administration of an agent that is associated with which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephrocalcinosis is seen in patients with chronic hypercalcemia, which can result from vitamin D hyperalimentation. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin D supplementation. Vitamin D deficiency occurs in patients with malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (D, E, A, and K) rather than neutral amino acids. In children, this deficiency causes rickets.

B) INCORRECT:

Bleeding complications such as hemorrhagic stroke or necrotizing enterocolitis (in infants) can result from vitamin E excess because large amounts of vitamin E impair absorption of procoagulatory vitamin K. In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin E supplementation. Though vitamin E deficiency may present with neurological deficits, such as ataxia and muscular weakness, it occurs in patients with impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease), which does not explain this patient's isolated neutral aminoaciduria.

C) CORRECT:

Treatment of Hartnup disease consists of both niacin supplementation (nicotinic acid) to correct vitamin B3 deficiency and replenishing the constant loss of amino acids with a high-protein diet. One of the most prominent side effects of niacin is facial flushing due to an increase in prostaglandin synthesis (leads to cutaneous vasodilation). Aspirin or ibuprofen, taken 30–60 minutes prior to administration of niacin, helps suppress prostaglandin production by inactivating cyclooxygenase.

Other adverse effects of niacin include hyperglycemia and hyperuricemia.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

D) INCORRECT:

Iatrogenic pseudotumor cerebri can result from chronic vitamin A toxicity (e.g., due to long-term supplementation). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin A supplementation. Vitamin A deficiency results from impaired fat reabsorption (e.g., cystic fibrosis, celiac disease) rather than malabsorption of neutral amino acids, and manifests with dry skin, night blindness, keratomalacia, and immunosuppression.

E) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced, irreversible retinopathy is a side effect of hydroxychloroquine, which is used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus. SLE can also present with a rash, photosensitivity, and proteinuria, as seen in this 5-year-old patient. However, it would not explain her isolated neutral aminoaciduria, which is highly specific for Hartnup disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcium oxalate kidney stones can result from excessive supplementation of vitamin C (breaks down into oxalate). In Hartnup disease, patients are vitamin B3 (niacin) deficient and do not require vitamin C supplementation. While Vitamin C deficiency can present with generalized weakness, patients usually have other symptoms, such as swollen gums, poor wound healing, perifollicular hemorrhage, and mucosal bleeding.
questions.hint: Intestinal and renal loss of neutral amino acids (e.g., tryptophan) is characteristic of Hartnup disease. Because tryptophan is a precursor of endogenous synthesis of vitamin B3, its loss results in vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency and symptoms of pellagra (rash on sun-exposed skin, ataxia with clumsiness, and recurrent falls).

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on the shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant and enzymatic cofactor that helps to enhance iron absorption in redox and hydroxylation reactions. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can lead to bruising and immunosuppression, the latter of which is consistent with this patient's 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. However, immunosuppression is not specific to scurvy and this patient does not have other dermatological manifestations of scurvy such as perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, and corkscrew hairs. Her history of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency (retinol deficiency) can be seen in conditions of fat malabsorption, such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatic insufficiency. Because vitamin A is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation, retinol deficiency results in dermatological and ophthalmological manifestations, such as xerosis cutis and Bitot spots. A deficiency in vitamin A can also cause immunosuppression, which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Moreover, this patient's recent history of stumbling in the dark most likely results from night blindness (nyctalopia), another common manifestation of vitamin A deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Zinc is an essential mineral required for the function of many enzymes. Zinc deficiency can cause diarrhea and immunosuppression. While zinc deficiency has dermatological manifestations, it causes acrodermatitis enteropathica rather than xerosis cutis. This patient does not have other expected symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as delayed wound healing, dysgeusia, and anosmia. Moreover, her frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) is a cofactor in acyl transfer reactions and fatty acid synthesis. While vitamin B5 deficiency manifests with nonspecific symptoms including dermatitis and diarrhea, it also causes alopecia and adrenal insufficiency, which are not observed in this patient. Furthermore, vitamin B5 deficiency would not explain this patient's frequent stumbling at night or recurrent infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a cofactor in redox reactions, such as those involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Riboflavin deficiency causes cheilosis and corneal vascularization. This patient has neither of these findings, and the presence of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva point to a different vitamin deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a cofactor in redox reactions and is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Niacin deficiency causes glossitis and can lead to pellagra in severe cases. Pellagra typically causes dermatitis involving the C3 and C4 dermatomes around the neck rather than generalized dry skin. Pellagra can also cause diarrhea, but this patient's diarrhea is likely due to celiac disease. Also, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva and frequent stumbling at night suggest a different vitamin deficiency.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.
questions.hint: This patient's dry skin, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva, as well as stumbling at night and a history of celiac disease are consistent with a specific vitamin deficiency.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of progressive nausea, vomiting, and right-sided flank pain for 2 days. The pain is colicky and radiates to the groin. He has a history of gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications are metformin and allopurinol. He recently began taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement after he read on the internet that it may help to prevent gout attacks. Physical examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Oral examination shows dental erosions. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an 8-mm stone in the right proximal ureter. Microscopic examination of a urine sample shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. An increased serum concentration of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute vitamin A toxicity, which can occur due to excessive supplement intake, can manifest with nausea and vomiting. However, it also typically causes vertigo and blurry vision, which this patient does not have. In addition, vitamin A toxicity is not associated with dental erosions or nephrolithiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperphosphatemia predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, unlike this patient's bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals, calcium phosphate stones appear on urine microscopy as wedge-shaped prisms. Also, this patient does not have a medical history (e.g., acute kidney injury, hyperparathyroidism), which is a risk factor for developing hyperphosphatemia. A history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases the risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of a different substance.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph showing crystals with the appearance of wedge-shaped prisms (can also be described as blunt-ended needles), some bound together forming a rosette.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B3 toxicity can cause hyperuricemia, which predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, uric acid stones appear on urine microscopy as rhomboid-shaped crystals, not bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of vitamin B3 toxicity, such as facial flushing (due to prostaglandin release) and hyperglycemia. His history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases his risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of another substance.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E toxicity is rare and typically associated with excess supplementation. It can cause bleeding due to inhibition of platelet aggregation and platelet adhesion as well as an alteration in warfarin metabolism. In infants, vitamin E toxicity has been associated with an increased risk of necrotizing enterocolitis. It is not known to cause nausea, vomiting, dental erosions, or nephrolithiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin C toxicity can result in calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis because vitamin C is metabolized to oxalate, and an increased serum oxalate concentration predisposes to stone formation. In particular, men with risk factors for nephrolithiasis, such as this patient with gout and type 2 diabetes mellitus, are at higher risk of stone formation secondary to excess vitamin C intake. Additional manifestations of vitamin C toxicity include dental erosions (due to the demineralizing activity of vitamin C), nausea, and vomiting, as seen in this patient. Diarrhea and fatigue may also be seen.

Vitamin C toxicity also increases dietary iron absorption and thus increases the risk of developing iron toxicity.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)

Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

F) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia, as seen in patients with gout, predisposes to nephrolithiasis. However, unlike this patient's bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals, uric acid stones appear on urine microscopy as rhomboid-shaped crystals. In addition, this patient takes allopurinol, a medication that reduces uric acid production. A history of taking large amounts of a multivitamin supplement increases the risk of nephrolithiasis from the toxicity of a different substance.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a urine sample with a pH of 5 (phase contrast microscopy; high magnification)

Multiple crystals of varying sizes and shapes can be seen (blue overlay).

Their diamond-shaped (rhomboid) form is one of the characteristic appearances of uric acid crystals, which only form in urine samples with a pH < 5.5 and are typically seen in patients with gout or in healthy individuals on a high-purine diet. Uric acid crystals may also appear barrel-shaped and needle-shaped (not seen in this image).
questions.hint: This patient's microscopic urinalysis shows bipyramidal, envelope-shaped crystals from a calcium oxalate kidney stone.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a rash and difficulty swallowing. His family emigrated from Nigeria 2 months ago. Examination shows an erythematous rash with fine yellow scales on his eyebrows and nasolabial folds. Oral examination shows an erythematous throat and swollen tongue. There is peeling and fissures of the skin at the corners of the mouth and cracking of the lips. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.6 g/dL; mean corpuscular volume is 89 μm3. Erythrocyte glutathione reductase assay shows an increased activity coefficient. This patient is most likely deficient in a vitamin that is a precursor to which of the following molecules?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiamine pyrophosphate is derived from vitamin B1 (thiamine). It is a cofactor for transketolase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Patients present with wet or dry beriberi, unlike this patient. Diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the transketolase activity in RBCs following administration of thiamine.

B) INCORRECT:

Coenzyme A is synthesized from pantothenate (vitamin B5) and is a cofactor for fatty acid synthase, fatty acyl CoA synthetase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Vitamin B5 deficiency is a rare condition that presents with adrenal insufficiency, enteritis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms (paresthesias, numbness); none of these features were seen in this patient. Diagnosis is confirmed by directly measuring the serum pantothenate level.

C) CORRECT:

Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) is synthesized from riboflavin (vitamin B2) and serves as a redox cofactor for various enzymes, including pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, succinate dehydrogenase, and glutathione reductase. Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measuring the activity coefficient of erythrocyte glutathione reductase in the absence and presence of FAD. An increase in enzyme activity upon addition of FAD, as seen in this patient, indicates a large amount of unsaturated enzyme due to riboflavin deficiency. Flavin mononucleotide (FMN) is another derivate of riboflavin that, like FAD, is used as a cofactor in redox reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) is synthesized from the precursor molecules vitamin B3 (niacin) and tryptophan. Niacin deficiency leads to development of pellagra, which manifests with diarrhea, dermatitis (redness, peeling, and scaling in sun-exposed areas), and dementia. Even though this patient has a skin rash, he lacks other features of pellagra. Niacin deficiency is confirmed by measuring serum levels of tryptophan or erythrocyte NAD/NADP ratio.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Methylcobalamin, one of the active forms of vitamin B12, is a cofactor for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase. Vitamin B12 deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia and peripheral neuropathy, which are not seen in this patient. Diagnosis is confirmed by direct measurement of serum B12 concentration.

F) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, is used as a cofactor, e.g., for cysthathione synthesis, protein catabolism, and heme synthesis. Deficiency can manifest with stomatitis, cheilosis, and seborrheic dermatitis as seen in this patient. However, patients with vitamin B6 deficiency will have sideroblastic anemia due to impaired heme synthesis, which is microcytic, not normocytic. Diagnosis is confirmed by direct measurement of plasma pyridoxal phosphate concentration.
questions.hint: The patient's seborrheic dermatitis (erythematous rash with fine yellow scales), pharyngeal hyperemia, glossitis, cheilitis, angular stomatitis, and normocytic-normochromic anemia are suggestive of vitamin B2 deficiency. The increased activity coefficient of erythrocyte glutathione reductase confirms this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of fatigue, facial rash, hair loss, and tingling of his hands and feet. He has followed a vegetarian diet for the past 3 years and has eaten 8 raw egg whites daily for the past year in preparation for a bodybuilding competition. Physical examination shows conjunctival injections and a scaly, erythematous rash around the eyes and mouth. Laboratory studies show decreased activity of propionyl-coenzyme A carboxylase in peripheral blood lymphocytes. Which of the following substances is most likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The conversion of succinate to fumarate is a reaction of the citric acid cycle that is catalyzed by succinate dehydrogenase, an enzyme that uses flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) as a cofactor. FAD is derived from riboflavin (vitamin B2) and serves as an electron carrier in redox reactions; it is not involved in carboxylation reactions.

B) INCORRECT:

The conversion of homocysteine and serine to cystathionine is catalyzed by cystathionine synthase, an enzyme that uses pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor. PLP is derived from pyridoxine (vitamin B6) and serves as a cofactor for transamination, decarboxylation, and deamination reactions, not for carboxylase enzymes.

C) INCORRECT:

Conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to ribulose-5-phosphate is a reaction of the hexose monophosphate shunt catalyzed by transketolase, an enzyme that uses thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) as a cofactor. TPP is derived from thiamine (vitamin B1) and serves as a cofactor for enzymes of carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism; it is not involved in carboxylation reactions.

D) INCORRECT:

Synthesis of adenine and other nitrogenous bases of DNA and RNA is dependent on tetrahydrofolic acid (THF), which generally serves as a cofactor in single-carbon transfers and methylation reactions. THF is not a cofactor of carboxylase enzymes.

E) INCORRECT:

The conversion of pyruvate to lactate is catalyzed by lactate dehydrogenase, an enzyme that uses nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) as a cofactor. NADH is derived from niacin (vitamin B3) and serves as an electron carrier in redox reactions. Consequently, lactate would be decreased in niacin deficiency. Biotin deficiency, leads to an accumulation of pyruvate, resulting in an increase in lactate.

F) CORRECT:

Biotin is needed as a cofactor for ATP-dependent carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a reaction catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. Excessive ingestion of avidin, a protein found in raw egg whites, causes impaired biotin absorption and can lead to clinically relevant deficiency, as seen in this patient. Additional carboxylase enzymes that use biotin as a cofactor include acetyl-CoA carboxylase, propionyl CoA carboxylase, and methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase.
questions.hint: Alopecia, dermatitis, conjunctivitis, fatigue, and paresthesias in the setting of extreme consumption of raw egg whites are concerning for biotin (vitamin B7) deficiency. Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes, such as propionyl-coenzyme A carboxylase.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. She has multiple erythematous pustules and nodules over her face, for which she has received erythromycin and topical benzoyl peroxide. She is concerned that the therapy is ineffective. The physician recommends a drug on the condition that the patient agrees to use oral contraceptives while taking it. The molecular structure of the drug most likely recommended by the physician closely resembles a drug used to treat which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

EGFR-positive non-small cell lung cancer can be treated with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as erlotinib. This class of drug exerts an antineoplastic effect by inhibiting downstream signaling of the growth factor, which has been implicated in the uncontrolled cellular growth and proliferation of EGFR-positive tumors. EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors are not structurally similar to the drug that was most likely recommended for this patient.

B) CORRECT:

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and isotretinoin are both retinoids. ATRA can be used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia, the M3 variant of acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). A t(15;17) translocation, which occurs in acute promyelocytic leukemia, changes the retinoic acid receptor so that granulocyte differentiation cannot occur under physiologic levels of retinoic acid. High doses of ATRA can induce remission by causing malignant cells to mature.

C) INCORRECT:

BRAF-positive metastatic melanoma can be treated with BRAF kinase inhibitors such as vemurafenib. These drugs target malignant cells that express the V600E mutation in the BRAF protein, inhibiting the normal proliferative cell signaling pathway and causing programmed cell death. BRAF kinase inhibitors are not structurally similar to the drug that was most likely recommended for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

ERBB2-positive gastric cancer can be treated with trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that inhibits oncogenic tyrosine kinase. Binding of the antibody to the extracellular portion of the ERBB2 receptor disables signaling through this pathway, arresting the neoplastic growth of the cell and leading to its death. Monoclonal antibodies are not structurally similar to the drug that was most likely recommended for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma treatment primarily involves monotherapy with either methotrexate or actinomycin D. Methotrexate is a vitamin B9 antimetabolite (not a vitamin A derivative like isotretinoin), whereas actinomycin D is an antibiotic with antineoplastic properties. Neither compound has structural similarities to the drug that was most likely recommended for this patient.
questions.hint: Patients with severe nodulocystic acne that is unresponsive to antibiotic therapy are most often prescribed isotretinoin, a member of the retinoid class of drugs.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of progressively worsening forgetfulness and frequent falls. He appears disheveled. On mental status examination, he is confused and oriented only to person. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze. He walks with wide-based, small steps and his gait is unsteady. An MRI of the brain is shown. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency can be caused by severe malnutrition associated with alcohol use disorder. It can present clinically with megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, irritability, memory loss, and dementia. However, it does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Although cobalamin is also used in the long-term treatment of patients with malnutrition and alcohol use disorder, supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

B) CORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency leads to neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction that cause the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy (i.e., confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia). Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in cerebral glucose and energy metabolism, which can be depleted in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or malnourishment. Early supplementation of thiamine would most likely have prevented this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency most commonly occurs due to severe malnutrition and/or alcohol use disorder and can cause cheilosis, glossitis, stomatitis, sideroblastic anemia, irritability, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not manifest with symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy and pyridoxine supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency can be caused by alcohol use disorder and malnutrition, it typically manifests clinically with pellagra, a clinical syndrome characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, glossitis, dementia, and, if not treated, death. It does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Supplementation would, thus, not have prevented this patient's condition.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9) deficiency may be caused by alcohol use disorder and/or malnutrition but typically presents with megaloblastic anemia and not with Wernicke encephalopathy. Folic acid replacement is also used for long-term treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy because it promotes neurogenesis. However, supplementation would not have prevented the development of this condition.
questions.hint: This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus), gait ataxia, and a brain MRI showing hyperintensities in the thalamus. These signs and symptoms suggest Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, weakness, constipation, decreased appetite, and intermittent flank pain. He takes ibuprofen for knee and shoulder pain. Physical examination shows mild tenderness bilaterally in the costovertebral areas. His serum calcium concentration is 11.2 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration is 2.5 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone concentration is 230 pg/mL. Which of the following steps in vitamin D metabolism is most likely increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The conversion of cholecalciferol to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver. It is stimulated by a higher substrate availability due to increased intake (e.g., from dietary supplements) or endogenous production of cholecalciferol, not by excess PTH in primary hyperparathyroidism.

B) CORRECT:

In primary hyperparathyroidism, excess PTH induces the expression of 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the proximal convoluted tubule cells of the kidney, which leads to an increased conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol into its metabolically active form 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is produced in the liver via hydroxylation of cholecalciferol, which has been previously synthesized in the skin under the influence of sunlight from 7-dehydrocholesterol.

In kidney disease, this step of vitamin D metabolism would be decreased due to a loss of 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity, leading to vitamin D deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

The conversion of ergocalciferol to 25-hydroxyergocalciferol by 25-hydroxylase takes place in the liver. This enzymatic reaction is stimulated by a higher substrate availability due to an increased intake of ergocalciferol (e.g., from plant sources, fortified food, or dietary supplements), not by excess PTH in primary hyperparathyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

The conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) takes place in the skin under the influence of ultraviolet B (UVB) rays. This enzymatic reaction is stimulated by exposure to sunlight, not by excess PTH in primary hyperparathyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

The deactivation of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol occurs in the kidneys and is stimulated by high concentrations of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. PTH impairs this step by decreasing the activity of the responsible enzyme, 24-hydroxylase.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (fatigue, weakness, constipation, decreased appetite, and intermittent flank pain, likely due to kidney stones) and laboratory abnormalities (increased calcium and PTH, decreased phosphorus) are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: An investigator is studying nutritional deficiencies in humans. A group of healthy volunteers are started on a diet deficient in pantothenic acid. After 4 weeks, several of the volunteers develop irritability, abdominal cramps, and burning paresthesias of their feet. These symptoms are fully reversed after reintroduction of pantothenic acid to their diet. The function of which of the following enzymes was most likely impaired in the volunteers during the study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K as a cofactor, not pantothenic acid (vitamin B5). Vitamin K deficiency manifests with excessive bleeding due to coagulation factor deficiency of factor X, factor IX, factor VII, and factor II.

B) INCORRECT:

Methionine synthase requires vitamin B12 (cobalamin) and vitamin B9 (folic acid) as cofactors. Deficiency of cobalamin or folic acid can cause irritability due to anemia (macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia). Cobalamin deficiency can also cause neurological symptoms (e.g., paresthesias). However, abdominal cramps would not be expected with cobalamin or folate deficiency, and symptoms of cobalamin or folate deficiency would not be expected after 4 weeks because the hepatic stores of these vitamins would not be depleted for several months in the case of folate and for several years in the case of cobalamin. Methionine synthase does not require pantothenic acid as a cofactor.
Image Description:

Methionine is an essential amino acid that generates sulfur-containing amino acids (i.e., cysteine, homocysteine, and taurine) as well as S-adenosyl methionine (SAM), a coenzyme of several methylation reactions, through the methionine cycle.

ATP donates adenosine to methionine, converting it to SAM. SAM then loses its methyl group to form S-adenosylhomocysteine, which loses its adenosine molecule to form homocysteine. Homocysteine can then enter three pathways: It can be converted to succinyl CoA (which enters the citric acid cycle), cysteine (from which taurine is generated; not shown here), or back to methionine. Methionine synthase catalyzes the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine in the presence of vitamin B12 and N5-methyltetrahydrofolate (N5-methyl-THF).

C) INCORRECT:

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase (DBH) is dependent on ascorbic acid (vitamin C), not pantothenic acid (vitamin B5). Ascorbic acid deficiency (scurvy) manifests with swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, and/or follicular hyperkeratosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Glutathione reductase is dependent on riboflavin (vitamin B2) and NADPH, which is derived from niacin (vitamin B3). Riboflavin deficiency is associated with corneal vascularization (pannus) and cheilosis. Niacin deficiency (pellagra) manifests with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Glutathione reductase activity is not dependent on pantothenic acid (vitamin B5).
Image Description:

In its reduced form (GSH), glutathione detoxifies free radicals and peroxides (here hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, on the right). This reaction is catalyzed by the glutathione peroxidase and results in oxidized glutathione (GSSG) and water (H2O). To convert the GSSG back to GSH, the catalyzing enzyme glutathione reductase requires NADPH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate hydrogen). One possible pathway that yields NADPH for reductive reactions is the pentose phosphate pathway (hexose monophosphate shunt). The enzyme glucose-6-P-dehydrogenase (G6PD) oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate and reduces NADP to NADPH.

The reduced glutathione is particularly important for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage. In its absence (e.g., due to G6PD deficiency), RBCs become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in hemolytic anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Alanine aminotransferase requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a cofactor, which is derived from pyridoxine (vitamin B6), not pantothenic acid (vitamin B5). Pyridoxine deficiency is very rare and manifests with convulsions, irritability, sideroblastic anemia, and peripheral neuropathy.
Image Description:

Alanine aminotransferase transfers the amino group (red) from alanine to α-ketoglutarate to yield pyruvate and glutamate. This transamination reaction is reversible and requires the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate (PLP).

F) CORRECT:

Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in the TCA cycle that converts α-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA. Enzymes that require CoA as a cofactor (e.g, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase) would be affected by pantothenic acid deficiency because pantothenic acid is required for synthesis of CoA. Pantothenic acid is also a component of the enzyme fatty acid synthase. Pantothenic acid deficiency is very rare in humans and usually occurs during war or famine. It manifests with irritability, abdominal cramps, and burning paresthesias of the feet (burning feet syndrome), as seen here.

Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase also requires other cofactors such as B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), and lipoic acid.
Image Description:

The citric acid cycle (CAC) or Krebs cycle occurs in the mitochondria. It is the common metabolic pathway at the end of the degradation of carbohydrates, lipids, and numerous amino acids. The CAC also produces precursors for the biosynthesis of other biologically important molecules.

The breakdown of glucose in glycolysis yields pyruvate, which enters the CAC in the form of acetyl-CoA. Fatty and amino acids also enter as acetyl-CoA. The condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate results in the formation of citrate or citric acid, which gives the cycle its name.

Each C2 molecule that enters the cycle leads to the production of 10 ATP, three molecules of NADH+H+, and one FADH2. In this way, each C2 molecule is completely oxidized to CO2 and water. The resulting oxaloacetate is recycled.
questions.hint: Pantothenic acid is also known as vitamin B5 and is a precursor to coenzyme A (CoA), a cofactor that is required for the transfer of acyl (2-carbon) groups.

questions.text: A previously healthy 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for numbness and tingling in her legs for the past 2 months. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and dry scaly lips with cracks at the corner of the mouth. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased in both lower limbs. Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.0 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Bone marrow biopsy shows erythroblasts with a ring of basophilic granules around the nucleus. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a substrate that acts as a cofactor in which of following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine in the presence of the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB). Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

The amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine share a common catabolic pathway. At first, phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase. This enzyme requires the cofactors tetrahydrobiopterin and dioxide. Tyrosine is then converted to 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate by tyrosine aminotransferase. The aromatic ring of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate is cleaved and the product is converted to fumarylacetoacetate by isomerization. Fumarate and acetoacetate are then produced by hydrolytic cleavage. Subsequently, acetoacetate can then be used to form acetoacetyl-CoA.

B) INCORRECT:

Tyrosine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of tyrosine to L-DOPA in the presence of the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB). Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

C) CORRECT:

DOPA decarboxylase catalyzes the conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine in the presence of the cofactor pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B6), which also serves as a cofactor in multiple other reactions, such as cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination reactions. Clinical features of vitamin B6 deficiency include glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia, as observed in the patient.
Image Description:

Overview of the biosynthesis and breakdown of the catecholamines dopamine, norepinephrine and epinephrine, starting with the amino acid phenylalanine and showing enzymes (blue text) and cofactors (blue highlighting).

The glucocorticoid cortisol induces expression of phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase and thus the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. The drug carbidopa (used, e.g., in Parkinson disease) inhibits DOPA decarboxylase and thus the peripheral conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine.

Congenital diseases may occur due to enzyme deficiencies, as shown here for phenylketonuria (1; defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase), albinism (2; defect in tyrosinase), and alkaptonuria (3; defect in homogentisate oxidase).

D) INCORRECT:

Dopamine β-hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine in the presence of the cofactors vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and Cu2+. Clinical features of vit. C deficiency include follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhage, ecchymoses, gingivitis, and impaired wound healing, which are not observed here. Moreover, most patients with vit. C deficiency will have either normocytic anemia (due to decreased iron absorption in small intestine) or macrocytic anemia (due to decreased conversion of folate to its active metabolite, folinic acid), unlike this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase catalyzes the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine in the presence of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), which donates a methyl group to norepinephrine. Synthesis and regeneration of SAM require the presence of vitamin B12 and folic acid. Patients with vit. B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency have low SAM levels, which leads to the development of megaloblastic anemia, unlike this patient's findings.
Image Description:

The coenzyme S-Adenosyl methionine (SAM) is composed of three parts: methionine (red), ribose (blue), and adenine (black). It plays an important role as a cofactor in methylation reactions.
questions.hint: In a patient taking an oral contraceptive, clinical features of peripheral neuropathy (paresthesias, decreased sensation in the extremities) and sideroblastic anemia (microcytic hypochromic anemia with sideroblasts in the bone marrow) suggest a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with celiac disease is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of generalized weakness and tingling around her mouth and in her fingertips. She also complains of abdominal cramps and nausea. In addition to following a gluten-free diet, she has been following a vegan diet for the past 2 years. Physical examination shows involuntary contractions of the muscle at the corner of her mouth and nose that are elicited by tapping on her right cheek. Her parathyroid hormone concentration is 153 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) in the skin following UVB light exposure. While decreased conversion can cause vitamin D deficiency, restricted sunlight exposure has not been reported in this patient. Moreover, the history of celiac disease makes another cause more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of renal 1α-hydroxylase (e.g., due to 1α-hydroxylase deficiency or chronic kidney failure) lead to vitamin D deficiency with subsequent hypocalcemia by impairing the conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D. However, 1α-hydroxylase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder and its onset would be expected within the first years of life. Furthermore, this patient has no signs of kidney failure and her celiac disease makes another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Because fish and dairy products are rich in vitamin D, this vegan patient may have slightly decreased dietary intake. However, plants and fortified foods (e.g., cereals, non-dairy milk, nutritional yeasts) are also rich sources of ergocalciferol, and these are consumed by vegans.

D) CORRECT:

Malabsorption syndromes (e.g., celiac disease, cystic fibrosis) can cause steatorrhea in some individuals, which leads to decreased intestinal absorption of fat-soluble vitamins such as ergocalciferol (vitamin D2). Individuals with celiac disease who do not report steatorrhea can still be at risk of vitamin deficiencies. Since vitamin D increases the intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate, prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency may lead to symptomatic hypocalcemia, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune disease is one of the most common causes of primary hypoparathyroidism, which can cause this patient's signs of hypocalcemia. In addition, celiac disease puts this patient at increased risk of developing other autoimmune disorders (especially those that are also associated with the HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8). However, her PTH level is elevated, which rules out hypoparathyroidism.
questions.hint: Involuntary facial muscle contractions when tapping on the cheek (Chvostek sign) together with paresthesia (tingling around the mouth and in the fingertips) and abdominal discomfort/nausea are highly indicative of tetany due to hypocalcemia, which would cause an elevated PTH.

questions.text: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

C) INCORRECT:

Underlying iron deficiency can manifest as microcytic anemia. Premature infants have lower iron stores and increased demand, and thus require supplementation in addition to the iron found in breast milk. However, exclusively breastfed infants < 4 months of age who were not born prematurely should receive adequate iron from breast milk alone. Exclusively breastfed infants ≥ 4 months of age should receive iron supplementation.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).

E) CORRECT:

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

F) INCORRECT:

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.
questions.hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of left lower leg pain after tripping on the stairs in her house. She reports that she has become a vegetarian and has been avoiding sunlight exposure for the last 2 years after watching a TV program on how to reduce the risk of malignancies. Physical examination shows tenderness over the left proximal shin. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows a fracture of the tibia and decreased bone density with thinning of the cortex. Impairment of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of this patient's x-ray findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

1-α-hydroxylation of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to create the final, active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), is mediated by the enzyme 1-α-hydroxylase in the renal proximal tubules. Adequate production of calcitriol may be impaired in patients with chronic renal failure. However, this process should not be affected in this patient with no evidence of kidney disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Cholecalciferol (and ergocalciferol, vitamin D2) is converted to 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol) in the liver by the enzyme vitamin D-25-hydroxylase. Impairment in the hydroxylation of cholecalciferol may be observed in patients with severe liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis) and would lead to a collection of vitamin D-deficient syndromes collectively called hepatic osteodystrophy. The production of 25-hydroxyvitamin D should not be affected in this patient who has no evidence of severe liver disease.

Since calcidiol or 25-OH D is the major circulating form of vitamin D in the body, it serves as the standard clinical laboratory measure of vitamin D status (replete vs deficiency) in patients with hypocalcemia, osteomalacia, rickets, and many other similar conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

7-dehydrocholesterol is synthesized from cholesterol. Adequate sunlight exposure is required to induce the conversion of this newly synthesized 7-dehydrocholesterol to the first precursor molecule in the vitamin D production cascade. However, the synthetic process that creates this precursor is not impaired in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Synthesis of cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) from 7-dehydrocholesterol, the first step in the vitamin D production cascade, requires adequate exposure to ultraviolet-B light (UVB light). Inadequate exposure to natural sunlight (e.g., cloudy climates, excessive clothing) is a major cause of vitamin D deficiency. Synthesis of cholecalciferol is also decreased in individuals with darker skin pigmentation. They require longer exposure to UVB light to make the same amount of cholecalciferol than lightly pigmented individuals because the higher production of cutaneous melanin acts as natural sun protection.
Image Description:

Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) is mainly synthesized in the body, but it can also be taken up with food and supplements.

Endogenous vitamin D synthesis involves a series of steps:
1. provitamin D3 (7-dehydrocholesterol) is synthesized from cholesterol in the liver and the skin.
2. provitamin D3 is converted in the skin with the help of UV radiation to vitamin D3.
3. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcidiol (25-hydroxycholecalciferol) in the liver (by the enzyme 25-hydroxylase)
4. Vitamin D3 is hydroxylated to calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3, which is biologically active) in the kidneys (by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase). Parathyroid hormone and cAMP promote this last step by stimulating 1α-hydroxylase. Calcium, phosphate, and FGF-23 inhibit 1α-hydroxylase.

E) INCORRECT:

Synthesis of ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2) from endogenous ergosterol is a photochemical conversion reaction induced in plants and fungi by ultraviolet-B (UVB) light. This process does not occur in humans.
questions.hint: Exposure to sunlight is essential for the initial step in the synthesis of active vitamin D. Decreased bone density and cortical thinning are typical radiologic features of osteomalacia, of which the most common cause is vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office because of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain for the past two months. The pain is sharp, colicky, and lasts about an hour after meals. Her stools are light in appearance and difficult to flush. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of various water-soluble vitamins may cause glossitis. It would not be caused by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (though a range of deficiencies can co-occur in some malabsorption conditions). The cholelithiasis and bile acid deficiency seen in this patient would not cause glossitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), or vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiencies, all of which are water-soluble vitamins. Fat malabsorption itself should not affect water-soluble vitamins, though some conditions include deficiency in both (e.g., concomitant B, D, and iron deficiency in celiac disease). Folic acid deficiency, for instance, can occur with a decreased intestinal surface area to absorb nutrients, increased physical demand (pregnancy), or decreased dietary intake. Pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) can be due to intestinal malabsorption or lack of intrinsic factor. Thiamine deficiency is commonly observed in individuals with alcohol use disorder or diets reliant on polished rice and milled white cereals. Check for other malabsorption syndromes as a differential diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Low bone mineral density is observed in patients with vitamin D deficiency, which can occur secondary to fat malabsorption, decreased intake, reduced sun exposure, decreased endogenous synthesis, or end-organ resistance to vitamin D. This patient is prone to developing other fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (vitamin A, vitamin E, vitamin K), as well.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired wound healing is observed in vitamin C deficiency and zinc deficiency, which result from inadequate dietary intake rather than fat malabsorption. Wound healing is also delayed in megaloblastic anemia and microcytic anemia. These can occur together with vitamin D deficiency in intestinal malabsorptive conditions. However, in a patient with fat malabsorption resulting from bile acid deficiency, delayed wound healing is not expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatic steatosis can be alcohol or non-alcohol related. It may be observed in patients with surplus nutritional intake, protein malnutrition, toxin-induced liver damage, or other underlying diseases. A dysbalance in fatty acid metabolism or peripheral fat absorption traps triglycerides and other fatty acids in the liver. Decreased apolipoprotein and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis can play a role. It is not expected in patients with fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and postprandial, colicky right upper quadrant pain suggest cholelithiasis. The floating, light-colored stool likely results from fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency. Therefore, this patient is prone to developing fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of repeated hospitalization for chronic pancreatitis comes to the physician because of difficulty walking and standing steadily. Neurological examination shows an unsteady, broad-based gait, distal muscle weakness, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and an abnormal Romberg test. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 89/μm3, and serum lactate dehydrogenase is 215 U/L. His serum haptoglobin is slightly decreased. A deficiency of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Deficiency of tocopherol (vitamin E deficiency) classically manifests with hemolytic anemia and symptoms of posterior column and spinocerebellar tract dysfunction (ataxia, loss of proprioception, and diminished reflexes). It is an uncommon condition in developed countries, but specific populations, such as patients with fat malabsorption disorders (e.g., chronic pancreatitis, abetalipoproteinemia, cystic fibrosis) are at significant risk. Vitamin E deficiency is harmful to neurons and red blood cells specifically as they are particularly sensitive to the oxidative damage that results from the loss of vitamin E antioxidative effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can occur due to malnutrition (e.g., from a restricted diet), and it may present with normocytic normochromic anemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with neurological dysfunction but presents with instead with dry, scaling skin of the lips and mouth (cheilosis). Affected individuals may also have vision loss due to corneal vascularization.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine deficiency (vitamin B6 deficiency) can occur with prolonged isoniazid administration and chronic alcohol use. It may present with neurological compromise, most often in the form of peripheral neuropathy, which could explain this patient's neurological findings. However, anemia associated with pyridoxine deficiency, if present, manifests as (microcytic) sideroblastic anemia, not (normocytic) hemolytic anemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration, which may manifest with neurological signs and symptoms similar to the ones seen in this patient, including ataxia and muscle weakness. However, cobalamin deficiency typically also manifests with symmetrical paresthesias of the extremities and dementia. In addition, it causes megaloblastic anemia. Finally, common risk factors for this vitamin deficiency include restricted diets, lack of intrinsic factor, or terminal ileum disease (e.g., Crohn disease), none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (vitamin B3 deficiency) can be seen in severe malnutrition, carcinoid syndrome, or Hartnup disease. Moderate deficiency may cause glossitis whereas severe cases may lead to pellagra. However, neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia would not be present.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.
questions.hint: In infants, excess of this vitamin has been associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of generalized pain and muscle weakness. She suffered a nondisplaced left ulnar fracture 3 months ago after lifting a heavy crate of books. She has had progressively worsening renal function over the past 2 years but has not yet started hemodialysis. An x-ray of the left wrist shows a healing fracture in the ulna with thinned cortices. There are multiple transverse radiolucent bands adjacent to the fracture, surrounded by a thin sclerotic margin. This patient's findings are most likely due to the impaired production of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

25-hydroxycholecalciferol is formed by the hydroxylation of cholecalciferol. Impaired production may cause osteomalacia. However, it is synthesized in the liver, not the kidney. Therefore liver failure, not renal failure, would cause a lack of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol.

B) CORRECT:

1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol is produced in the mitochondria of the proximal convoluted tubule cells of the kidney. The enzyme 1α-hydroxylase hydroxylates 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, the active form of vitamin D3. Kidney failure leads to impaired production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, which impairs mineralization and remodeling of osteoid tissue, called osteomalacia in adults. Osteomalacia softens the bone, causing pain and tenderness as well as pathological fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Ergosterol is an inactive precursor of vitamin D2 that is derived from dietary sources (e.g., mushrooms, fortified food). It is not produced endogenously, so its production would not be impaired by renal failure. Furthermore, a lack of ergosterol would not cause osteomalacia, which is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin by cleaving 7-dehydrocholesterol via irradiation with UV light. A lack of cholecalciferol causes osteomalacia. However, as this patient has a history of chronic kidney disease, production of another metabolite is more likely impaired.

E) INCORRECT:

7-dehydrocholesterol is an inactive precursor of vitamin D3 and impaired production may cause osteomalacia. However, it is not synthesized in the kidney. It is synthesized in the liver from cholesterol under the influence of the enzyme cholesterol dehydrogenase. Therefore, liver failure, not renal failure, would cause a lack of 7-dehydrocholesterol.
questions.hint: The presence of bone pain in an adult along with Looser zones (transverse radiolucent bands) and thin cortices on x-ray indicates osteomalacia. This patient's osteomalacia is caused by defective vitamin D metabolism due to renal failure.

questions.text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoride crosses the placental barrier and is present in breast milk following environmental exposure. Most newborns have already accumulated measurable levels at birth. In regions where the drinking water is not fluoridated, the current recommendation is to administer fluoride to children but not before the age of 6 months due to the risk of fluorosis. Using fluoride to support dental hygiene protects against dental caries, which is not a life-threatening condition.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.
questions.hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man with Crohn disease is admitted to the hospital because of colicky abdominal pain, constipation, and vomiting. Endoscopy shows a stricture in the terminal ileum. The ileum is surgically resected after endoscopic balloon dilation fails to relieve the obstruction. Three years later, he returns for a follow-up examination. He takes no medications. This patient is most likely to have which of the following physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can manifest with symmetric neurological deficits, including limb weakness and ataxia. Vitamin B12 is a cofactor of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase and methionine synthase, both of which are necessary for proper neuronal function. Because the terminal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption, resection of this structure can result in vitamin B12 deficiency unless properly supplemented.

Ileocecal resection can also result in the malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (due to bile acid malabsorption) and micronutrients like magnesium.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyporeflexia and bradycardia are manifestations of severe hypermagnesemia. Causes of hypermagnesemia include decreased elimination (e.g., renal insufficiency), increased intake (e.g., oversupplementation), and increased tissue breakdown (e.g., rhabdomyolysis). Because the terminal ileum is an important site of magnesium absorption, its removal can result in hypomagnesemia rather than hypermagnesemia.

C) INCORRECT:
