Gingival swelling and bleeding would be consistent with vitamin C deficiency (scurvy). Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin that functions as an important cofactor in collagen synthesis. This patient is at risk of a malabsorption syndrome but vitamin C absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making significant vitamin C deficiency unlikely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pallor with koilonychia is consistent with iron deficiency anemia. Iron is first reduced to its ferrous form (Fe2+) before being absorbed in the duodenum and upper jejunum. This patient is at risk of a malabsorption syndrome but iron absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making these findings unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Glossitis and pellagra are consistent with niacin deficiency. Niacin is a water-soluble vitamin that is an important coenzyme in redox reactions. This patient is at risk of malabsorption of several vitamins and micronutrients, but niacin absorption is not dependent on the terminal ileum, making significant niacin deficiency unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: The distal ileum is the primary site of vitamin B12 absorption (in the form of B12-intrinsic factor complex).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dysuria and urinary urgency. He had been treated for urinary tract infections twice in the past 6 months. He is currently taking infliximab. Cystoscopy shows pearl-like plaques on the bladder wall. Biopsy of these lesions shows a focal layer of stratified squamous epithelium with hyperkeratosis. If the patient's bladder finding is caused by a vitamin deficiency, which of the following features is also most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carpopedal spasm is seen in hypocalcemia caused by severe vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D deficiency manifests in adults as osteomalacia and may cause bone pain, fractures, difficulty walking, and myopathy, but it would not cause keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder.

B) INCORRECT:

Perifollicular hemorrhage, which is seen in scurvy, is a manifestation of vitamin C deficiency. Symptoms of scurvy include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, curly body hair, follicular hyperkeratosis, and generalized weakness, but not keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder. In addition, vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin, meaning deficiency of it would not be associated with fat malabsorption.

C) INCORRECT:

Nystagmus is a manifestation of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by a vitamin B1 deficiency. This encephalopathy is commonly seen in patients with long-standing alcohol use disorder and also manifests with confusion and ataxia, but not with keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder. Moreover, vitamin B1 is a water-soluble vitamin, meaning deficiency of it would not be associated with fat malabsorption.

D) INCORRECT:

Photodermatitis, which is seen in pellagra, is associated with vitamin B3 deficiency. Pellagra is characterized by "the four D's": diarrhea, dermatitis/glossitis, dementia, and death. It is not associated with keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Circumcorneal neovascularization is a manifestation of vitamin B2 deficiency. Other symptoms of this deficiency include cheilitis, glossitis, stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, and normochromic-normocytic anemia. It does not cause keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder.

F) CORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency can cause ocular disorders such as xerophthalmia, Bitot spots, corneal xerosis, keratomalacia, and night blindness. Other signs of vitamin A deficiency include poor bone growth, hyperkeratosis, xeroderma, immunosuppression, and squamous metaplasia. Vitamin A deficiency has a higher prevalence in patients with fat malabsorption disorders, such as Crohn disease.

G) INCORRECT:

Intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) is a manifestation of vitamin A toxicity. Other clinical manifestations of acute vitamin A toxicity include headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, loss of appetite, dry skin, and alopecia. Chronic intoxication may lead to osteoporosis, bone pain, and psychiatric changes, but it would not cause keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the bladder.
questions.hint: The biopsy finding of stratified squamous epithelium with hyperkeratosis suggests a diagnosis of squamous metaplasia of the bladder urothelium. Vitamin A is required for proper differentiation of specialized epithelial cells (e.g., columnar cells of the pancreatic duct, respiratory tract, and conjunctiva, or urothelial cells). Vitamin A deficiency can result in metaplasia of these cells to keratinizing cells.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of extracellular pH changes on the substrates for the citric acid cycle. Which of the following substances is required for the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme marked by the arrow in the overview of the citric acid cycle?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a constituent of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), which is a cofactor for the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Citrate synthase does not use TPP as a cofactor.

B) CORRECT:

Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is a component of coenzyme A (CoA), which is a carrier of acyl groups (e.g., acetyl-CoA, succinyl-CoA, or methylmalonyl-CoA). In the glycolytic pathway and citric acid cycle, the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase, citrate synthase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and succinyl-CoA synthetase catalyze reactions that involve CoA.
Image Description:

The citric acid cycle (CAC) or Krebs cycle occurs in the mitochondria. It is the common metabolic pathway at the end of the degradation of carbohydrates, lipids, and numerous amino acids. The CAC also produces precursors for the biosynthesis of other biologically important molecules.

The breakdown of glucose in glycolysis yields pyruvate, which enters the CAC in the form of acetyl-CoA. Fatty and amino acids also enter as acetyl-CoA. The condensation of acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate results in the formation of citrate or citric acid, which gives the cycle its name.

Each C2 molecule that enters the cycle leads to the production of 10 ATP, three molecules of NADH+H+, and one FADH2. In this way, each C2 molecule is completely oxidized to CO2 and water. The resulting oxaloacetate is recycled.

C) INCORRECT:

Guanosine diphosphate (GDP) is phosphorylated to GTP during the enzymatic conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate, which is catalyzed by succinyl-CoA synthetase. Citrate synthase does not use GDP as a cofactor.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipoic acid is a cofactor for the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Citrate synthase does not use lipoic acid as a cofactor.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a constituent of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), which is a cofactor for the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and malate dehydrogenase. Citrate synthase does not use NAD as a cofactor.

F) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a constituent of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which is a cofactor for the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and succinate dehydrogenase. Citrate synthase does not use FAD as a cofactor.
questions.hint: The substance required for this reaction is a vitamin that is a byproduct of both fatty-acid and carbohydrate metabolism.

questions.text:
Patient information
Age: 82 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have been getting these large bruises on my arms and legs.”
History of Present Illness:

his wife noticed 6 weeks ago that he had bruising on the bilateral lower extremities
additional ecchymoses developed on the bilateral upper extremities 2 weeks ago
feels increasingly fatigued
has pain in the elbows, hips, and knees

was unable to complete his final cycle of chemotherapy for non-small cell lung carcinoma because of the pain
has not had trauma or prior episodes of significant bleeding

Past Medical History: 

hypertension
benign prostatic hyperplasia
osteoarthritis
non-small cell lung carcinoma treated with resection; currently undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy

Medications:

amlodipine
lisinopril
tamsulosin
acetaminophen
cisplatin-based chemotherapy

Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial History: 

lives with his wife
has been eating sparingly
has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 60 years


Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.6°C(97.8°F)
88/min
20/min
128/83 mm Hg
96%
175 cm(5 ft 9 in)
53 kg(117 lb)
17 kg/m2




Appearance: pale, tired-appearing, cachectic; sitting in a wheelchair
HEENT: swollen gums; mild mucosal bleeding

Pulmonary: diminished breath sounds in the left lower lung field; moderate inspiratory wheezes bilaterally; no rales or rhonchi
Cardiac: normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft; nontender; nondistended; normal bowel sounds
Extremities: symmetrically cool; no edema
Skin: coiled hairs with perifollicular hemorrhages; multiple ecchymoses of the bilateral upper and lower extremities

Neurologic: symmetrically decreased sensation to pinprick, vibration, and fine touch in the distal lower extremities


Administration of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) results in impaired collagen synthesis and easily-damaged connective tissue, which manifests with swollen gums and mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs (corkscrew hairs), perifollicular hemorrhages, anemia (fatigue, pallor), and easy bruising (e.g., multiple ecchymoses). His joint pain may be caused by hemarthroses from vitamin C deficiency or may be due to his underlying osteoarthritis. Populations at increased risk for developing nutritional deficiencies include individuals with substance use disorders, the elderly, and patients who are chronically ill, such as this man with non-small cell lung carcinoma who may have poor intake due to loss of appetite and chemotherapy-induced nausea. The treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency is associated with several ocular and dermatologic manifestations, including night blindness, xerophthalmia, keratomalacia, Bitot spots, and xerosis. In addition, vitamin A deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency can cause osteomalacia and symptoms of hypocalcemia (e.g., paresthesias, muscle spasms). It does not cause anemia (fatigue, pallor), mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency include ataxia and spasticity (due to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord) and manifestations of neuropsychiatric diseases such as dementia and depression. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (decreased sensation in the lower extremities) as well as fatigue and pallor (due to sideroblastic anemia). However, this patient's peripheral neuropathy is likely caused by cisplatin-based chemotherapy. Other symptoms of vitamin B6 deficiency include cheilitis, glossitis, and stomatitis. Moreover, vitamin B6 deficiency does not cause mucosal bleeding, coiled hairs, perifollicular hemorrhages, or ecchymoses.

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is a cofactor for factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X of the coagulation cascade; vitamin K deficiency causes coagulopathy that could manifest with ecchymoses, mucosal bleeding, and pallor. However, vitamin K deficiency does not cause coiled hairs. In addition, perifollicular hemorrhages are highly specific for another nutritional deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's history of decreased appetite and low BMI (17 kg/m2) suggest malnutrition, which is complicated by a vitamin deficiency as indicated by impaired wound healing and an impaired immune response.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to a rural field hospital set up by an international health organization in northern Africa. The man is brought to the hospital by his cousin after being found naked and disoriented in a garden far away from where he lives. His cousin says this is not the first time the patient has got lost on his way home. The patient has also had diarrhea for several months. He has no history of previous illnesses and does not take any medications. Physical examination shows reddening of the tongue and the findings in the photograph. He is oriented only to person and his short-term memory is impaired. This patient most likely has a deficiency of a substance that is derived from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Niacin deficiency leads to diarrhea, disorientation, glossitis (i.e., reddening of the tongue), and symmetric dermatitis that affects sun-exposed areas (commonly the neck; also known as “Casal necklace”), as seen in this patient. The majority of niacin is obtained through diet, but small amounts of vitamin B3 (niacin) are synthesized endogenously from the amino acid tryptophan. In resource-poor countries where food grains are not nixtamalized, pellagra is more common. Pellagra can also occur with chronic malnutrition (e.g., due to alcohol use disorder, eating disorders), Hartnup disease, carcinoid syndrome, and isoniazid therapy.

Tryptophan is also a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin via the enzymes tryptophan hydroxylase and 5-hydroxytryptophan decarboxylase.
Image Description:

Important cofactors and constituents appear in blue boxes.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycine is a precursor for the synthesis of porphyrins, which are used to produce heme. Decreased porphyrin production (due to δ ALA synthase inhibition) is seen in lead poisoning, which can cause gastrointestinal symptoms and memory impairment, both of which are seen here. However, lead poisoning typically causes constipation rather than diarrhea and does not result in glossitis or cutaneous hyperpigmentation. Instead, features of sideroblastic anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue), neuropathy, and bluish discoloration of the gums (Burton line) would be expected. This patient's condition is not caused by the decreased production of a glycine derivative.

C) INCORRECT:

Histidine is a precursor for the synthesis of histamine. Histamine deficiency is essentially nonexistent. This patient's condition is caused by a deficiency of another substance.

D) INCORRECT:

Glutamate is a precursor for the synthesis of GABA and glutathione. Deficiency of reduced forms of glutathione is seen in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, which causes recurring hemolytic crises and manifests with anemia, jaundice, and dark urine, none of which are seen here. This patient's condition is caused by a deficiency of another amino acid.

E) INCORRECT:

Arginine is a precursor for the synthesis of urea, creatine, and nitric oxide (NO). Decreased urea production (urea cycle defect) causes hyperammonemia, which typically manifests during the neonatal period with asterixis, vomiting, and somnolence. Decreased creatine production (congenital creatine deficiency) manifests during early childhood with intellectual disability and, possibly, myopathy. Decreased NO synthesis is implicated in the pathogenesis of delayed gastric emptying, pulmonary hypertension, accelerated atherosclerosis, and recurrent thrombosis. This patient's condition is not caused by the deficiency of an arginine derivative.

F) INCORRECT:

Phenylalanine is a precursor in the synthesis of tyrosine, which is used to produce melanin, iodinated tyrosine molecules (e.g., monoiodotyrosine), and catecholamines. Decreased melanin production occurs in type 1 oculocutaneous albinism and phenylketonuria, which manifest at birth and during early childhood, respectively, with generalized hypopigmentation, in contrast to the hyperpigmentation in this adult. Decreased production of iodinated tyrosine molecules (e.g., due to defective thyroid peroxidase activity) causes congenital hypothyroidism. Decreased catecholamine production is rare and causes orthostatic hypotension, nasal stuffiness, and hypoglycemic episodes. This patient's condition is not caused by the deficiency of a phenylalanine derivative.
questions.hint: This is an essential, aromatic amino acid.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She has been a vegetarian ever since she watched a documentary about industrial livestock farming. Last month, she joined a group of friends who toured a dairy farm in their neighboring village in Montana, which convinced her to become a vegan and consume only unprocessed foods. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. The parents are concerned that she will not get enough nutrition. The patient just finished her soccer season and plans on joining the ski team for the winter season next month. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. She is annoyed about the concerns of her parents and believes a vegan diet will not only help save animal lives but also protect the planet. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 Ib); BMI is 23 kg/m2. The physician should counsel the patient that without supplements, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this girl will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet, chronic alcohol use), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

B) INCORRECT:

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this girl will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based products such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this girl will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this girl will develop vitamin B6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).

E) CORRECT:

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D, which is often deficient in individuals who live in northern latitudes (like this patient from Montana), especially during the Winter season.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.
questions.hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of progressively worsening forgetfulness and frequent falls. He appears disheveled. On mental status examination, he is confused and oriented only to person. Neurologic examination shows horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze. He walks with wide-based, small steps and his gait is unsteady. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral thalamic hyperintensities. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency can be caused by severe malnutrition associated with alcohol use disorder. It can present clinically with megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, irritability, memory loss, and dementia. However, it does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Although cobalamin is also used in the long-term treatment of patients with malnutrition and alcohol use disorder, supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

B) CORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency leads to neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction that cause the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy (i.e., confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia). Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in cerebral glucose and energy metabolism, which can be depleted in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or malnourishment. Early supplementation of thiamine would most likely have prevented this patient's condition.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T2-weighted; axial view)

Bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities are visible on the medial portions of the thalamus (green overlay).

This finding is characteristic of Wernicke encephalopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency most commonly occurs due to severe malnutrition and/or alcohol use disorder and can cause cheilosis, glossitis, stomatitis, sideroblastic anemia, irritability, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not manifest with symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy and pyridoxine supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Although niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency can be caused by alcohol use disorder and malnutrition, it typically manifests clinically with pellagra, a clinical syndrome characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, glossitis, dementia, and, if not treated, death. It does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Supplementation would, thus, not have prevented this patient's condition.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9) deficiency may be caused by alcohol use disorder and/or malnutrition but typically presents with megaloblastic anemia and not with Wernicke encephalopathy. Folic acid replacement is also used for long-term treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy because it promotes neurogenesis. However, supplementation would not have prevented the development of this condition.
questions.hint: This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus), gait ataxia, and hyperintensities in the thalamus. These signs and symptoms suggest Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).

D) CORRECT:

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.
questions.hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 2710-g (6-lb) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks of gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation unnecessary. Individuals planning pregnancy should be supplied with folic acid beginning ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continuing until 12 weeks' gestation to prevent neural tube defects. Infants born to folate-deficient mothers can develop megaloblastic anemia, but this carries no immediate postnatal complication or risk of mortality.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.
questions.hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. The patient should be counseled that without supplements, there is an increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this patient will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

B) INCORRECT:

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this patient will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based sources such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this patient will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this patient will develop vitamin B6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).

E) CORRECT:

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.
questions.hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter because of progressive memory loss and weakness over the past 6 months. She is now unable to perform activities of daily living and has had several falls in her apartment. She has diarrhea. She drinks one pint of vodka daily. Examination shows glossitis and a hyperpigmented rash on her face and arms. On mental status examination, she is oriented to place and person only. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency results in clinical findings collectively known as scurvy, which can include ecchymoses, bleeding gums, and petechiae, none of which is seen in this patient. The primary cause of ascorbic acid deficiency is prolonged dietary deficiency. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's constellation of symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use and result in anterograde amnesia (as in Korsakoff syndrome). However, it usually manifests with features of wet beriberi (high-output cardiac failure), dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy), and/or Wernicke encephalopathy (oculomotor dysfunction, gait ataxia, confusion), none of which are seen here. Other causes of vitamin B1 deficiency include malnutrition, prolonged vomiting and diarrhea, and bariatric surgery. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of glossitis and dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

While vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency can cause glossitis, it is also associated with angular cheilitis and stomatitis. Common causes of vitamin B2 deficiency include insufficient intake or absorption (e.g., vegan diet, lactose intolerance). Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of diarrhea and dementia.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use and result in glossitis and seborrheic dermatitis. However, this patient does not have other features of vitamin B6 deficiency such as cheilitis, stomatitis, and seizures, making another vitamin deficiency more likely. Other causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include malnutrition and chronic kidney and liver disease.

E) CORRECT:

Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency can result in pellagra, a systemic disease that is characterized by glossitis and the 4 Ds: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and possible death. Common causes of pellagra include insufficient niacin intake, chronic alcohol use (as seen here), and conditions caused by tryptophan deficiency such as Hartnup disease (due to decreased renal and intestinal tryptophan absorption) and carcinoid syndrome (due to increased tryptophan metabolism). This patient's presentation is concerning for severe niacin deficiency, and urgent vitamin B3supplementation is indicated to prevent further deterioration.

Key learning point: Pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia, results from a deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin), often associated with chronic alcoholism or malnutrition.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.
questions.hint: This woman has alcohol use disorder and presents with glossitis, diarrhea, symptoms of dementia (e.g., progressive memory loss), and dermatitis (hyperpigmented rash on sun-exposed areas), making pellagra the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with oral pain and spontaneous gum bleeding for two weeks. His diet consists mostly of bread and tea. He denies any recent infections or trauma. Examination shows swollen, bluish-purple gums with several loose teeth, multiple ecchymoses on the lateral sides of the arms, and poor dentition. He complains of fatigue. Bloodwork reveals a normal platelet count.
Which deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency affects calcium absorption and bone mineralization, leading to osteomalacia, not the gingival and bleeding symptoms seen here. The normal platelet count and dietary history do not support vitamin D deficiency, which is more related to inadequate sun exposure or malabsorption.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency impairs collagen synthesis due to its role as a cofactor in hydroxylating proline and lysine residues. This results in weakened connective tissues and fragile capillaries, manifesting as gingival hypertrophy, spontaneous gum bleeding, loose teeth, and ecchymoses. The patient's diet, lacking fresh fruits and vegetables, is deficient in vitamin C. The normal platelet count supports a collagen stability issue rather than a hematologic disorder. Fatigue is also associated with vitamin C deficiency due to its role in cellular metabolism and iron absorption.

Key learning point: Gingival hypertrophy with enlarged, bluish purple friable gums is a classic sign of scurvy, which is caused by vitamin C deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K is essential for activating clotting factors, and its deficiency results in a bleeding diathesis with prolonged prothrombin time. It does not cause structural changes in gingival tissue or loose teeth, which are indicative of collagen synthesis defects. The normal platelet count and specific oral findings suggest capillary fragility, not a coagulation defect.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects mucosal surfaces, vision, and immune function, leading to night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not impair collagen synthesis or vascular integrity, which are necessary for the symptoms of gum bleeding and ecchymoses. The patient's presentation does not align with vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: You are seeing a 73-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her son because of a 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Her son reports that she often stumbles into the nightstand when getting up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent diarrhea. She is 173 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 18. On examination, she has generalized dry skin, multiple bruises on her shins, and triangular keratin plaques on the temporal conjunctiva. A deficiency of which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a cofactor in redox reactions and is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Niacin deficiency causes glossitis and can lead to pellagra in severe cases. Pellagra typically causes dermatitis involving the C3 and C4 dermatomes around the neck rather than generalized dry skin. Pellagra can also cause diarrhea, but this patient's diarrhea is likely due to celiac disease. Also, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva and frequent stumbling at night suggest a different vitamin deficiency.

B) CORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency (retinol deficiency) can be seen in conditions of fat malabsorption, such as inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease), celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, and pancreatic insufficiency. Because vitamin A is involved in epithelial cell differentiation and retinal pigmentation, retinol deficiency results in dermatological and ophthalmological manifestations, such as xerosis cutis and Bitot spots. A deficiency in vitamin A can also cause immunosuppression, which explains this patient's recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Moreover, this patient's recent history of stumbling in the dark most likely results from night blindness (nyctalopia), another common manifestation of vitamin A deficiency.

Key learning point: Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness, xerosis cutis, Bitot spots on the conjunctiva, and increased susceptibility to infections, especially in the context of fat malabsorption.

C) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a cofactor in redox reactions, such as those involved in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. Riboflavin deficiency causes cheilosis and corneal vascularization. This patient has neither of these findings, and the presence of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva point to a different vitamin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Zinc is an essential mineral required for the function of many enzymes. Zinc deficiency can cause diarrhea and immunosuppression. While zinc deficiency has dermatological manifestations, it causes acrodermatitis enteropathica rather than xerosis cutis. This patient does not have other expected symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as delayed wound healing, dysgeusia, and anosmia. Moreover, her frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant and enzymatic cofactor that helps to enhance iron absorption in redox and hydroxylation reactions. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can lead to bruising and immunosuppression, the latter of which is consistent with this patient's 3-month history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. However, immunosuppression is not specific to scurvy and this patient does not have other dermatological manifestations of scurvy such as perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, and corkscrew hairs. Her history of frequent stumbling at night and triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva suggest a different deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's dry skin, triangular keratin plaques on the conjunctiva, as well as stumbling at night and a history of celiac disease are consistent with a specific vitamin deficiency.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, colicky, and occurs for about an hour after meals. She reports that her stools are light in color and difficult to flush. On examination, there is tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired wound healing is observed in vitamin C deficiency and zinc deficiency, which result from inadequate dietary intake rather than fat malabsorption. Wound healing is also delayed in megaloblastic anemia and microcytic anemia. These can occur together with vitamin D deficiency in intestinal malabsorptive conditions. However, in a patient with fat malabsorption resulting from bile acid deficiency, delayed wound healing is not expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of various water-soluble vitamins may cause glossitis. It would not be caused by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (though a range of deficiencies can co-occur in some malabsorption conditions). The cholelithiasis and bile acid deficiency seen in this patient would not cause glossitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), or vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiencies, all of which are water-soluble vitamins. Fat malabsorption itself should not affect water-soluble vitamins, though some conditions include deficiency in both (e.g., concomitant B, D, and iron deficiency in celiac disease). Folic acid deficiency, for instance, can occur with a decreased intestinal surface area to absorb nutrients, increased physical demand (pregnancy), or decreased dietary intake. Pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) can be due to intestinal malabsorption or lack of intrinsic factor. Thiamine deficiency is commonly observed in individuals with alcohol use disorder or diets reliant on polished rice and milled white cereals. Check for other malabsorption syndromes as a differential diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatic steatosis can be alcohol or non-alcohol related. It may be observed in patients with surplus nutritional intake, protein malnutrition, toxin-induced liver damage, or other underlying diseases. A dysbalance in fatty acid metabolism or peripheral fat absorption traps triglycerides and other fatty acids in the liver. Decreased apolipoprotein and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis can play a role. It is not expected in patients with fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Low bone mineral density is observed in patients with vitamin D deficiency, which can occur secondary to fat malabsorption, decreased intake, reduced sun exposure, decreased endogenous synthesis, or end-organ resistance to vitamin D. This patient is prone to developing other fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (vitamin A, vitamin E, vitamin K), as well.

Key learning point: Fat malabsorption from cholelithiasis can cause deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin D, increasing the risk of low bone mineral density and osteomalacia.
questions.hint: This patient's decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and postprandial, colicky right upper quadrant pain suggest cholelithiasis. The floating, light-colored stool likely results from fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency. Therefore, this patient is prone to developing fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.

questions.text: You are seeing a 59-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder who is brought to the emergency department by a friend due to progressively worsening forgetfulness and frequent falls. On mental status examination, he is confused and oriented only to person. Neurologic examination reveals horizontal nystagmus on lateral gaze. His gait is wide-based, with small steps, and is unsteady. MRI of the brain shows bilateral thalamic hyperintensities. Supplementation of which one of the following is most likely to have prevented his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9) deficiency may be caused by alcohol use disorder and/or malnutrition but typically presents with megaloblastic anemia and not with Wernicke encephalopathy. Folic acid replacement is also used for long-term treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy because it promotes neurogenesis. However, supplementation would not have prevented the development of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency can be caused by severe malnutrition associated with alcohol use disorder. It can present clinically with megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, irritability, memory loss, and dementia. However, it does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Although cobalamin is also used in the long-term treatment of patients with malnutrition and alcohol use disorder, supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Although niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency can be caused by alcohol use disorder and malnutrition, it typically manifests clinically with pellagra, a clinical syndrome characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, glossitis, dementia, and, if not treated, death. It does not manifest with the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy seen here. Supplementation would, thus, not have prevented this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency most commonly occurs due to severe malnutrition and/or alcohol use disorder and can cause cheilosis, glossitis, stomatitis, sideroblastic anemia, irritability, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not manifest with symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy and pyridoxine supplementation would not have prevented this patient's condition.

E) CORRECT:

Thiamine deficiency leads to neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction that cause the symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy (i.e., confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, and gait ataxia). Thiamine (vitamin B1) is a cofactor for critical enzymes involved in cerebral glucose and energy metabolism, which can be depleted in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or malnourishment. Early supplementation of thiamine would most likely have prevented this patient's condition.

Key learning point: Wernicke encephalopathy is prevented by thiamine (vitamin B1) supplementation, especially in individuals with alcohol use disorder or malnutrition.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T2-weighted; axial view)

Bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities are visible on the medial portions of the thalamus (green overlay).

This finding is characteristic of Wernicke encephalopathy.
questions.hint: This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (e.g., nystagmus), gait ataxia, and hyperintensities in the thalamus. These signs and symptoms suggest Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-day-old boy who is exclusively breast-fed and brought to your clinic by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term following an uncomplicated delivery and received all standard treatment and testing before being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination is normal. Without additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which one of the following conditions?

She reports eating a well-balanced diet that includes vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. She has no history of serious medical illness and does not take any medications. questions.text: You are seeing a 55-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her daughter because of progressive memory loss and weakness over the past 6 months. She is now unable to perform activities of daily living and has experienced several falls at home. She also has diarrhea. She drinks one pint of vodka daily. On examination, she has glossitis and a hyperpigmented rash on her face and arms. On mental status examination, she is oriented to place and person only. Which one of the following deficiencies is most likely present in this patient?

However, this patient does not have other features of vitamin B6 deficiency such as cheilitis, stomatitis, and seizures, making another vitamin deficiency more likely. Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use and result in anterograde amnesia (as in Korsakoff syndrome). Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency results in clinical findings collectively known as scurvy, which can include ecchymoses, bleeding gums, and petechiae, none of which is seen in this patient. The primary cause of ascorbic acid deficiency is prolonged dietary deficiency. Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's constellation of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

While vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency can cause glossitis, it is also associated with angular cheilitis and stomatitis. Common causes of vitamin B2 deficiency include insufficient intake or absorption (e.g., vegan diet, lactose intolerance). Another vitamin deficiency is more likely to explain this patient's additional symptoms of diarrhea and dementia.
questions.hint: This woman has alcohol use disorder and presents with glossitis, diarrhea, symptoms of dementia (e.g., progressive memory loss), and dermatitis (hyperpigmented rash on sun-exposed areas), making pellagra the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: You have just delivered a male newborn weighing 2710 g at 38 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2. The pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Breastfeeding is initiated. Which one of the following is indicated in this newborn to prevent a potentially life-threatening condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron stores in newborns are sufficient for the first 6 months of life, so immediate postnatal supplementation is not routinely required. Although breast milk contains only a small amount of iron, its bioavailability is high, which helps protect infants from iron deficiency during this period. After around 6 months of age, the introduction of iron-rich foods is recommended to prevent iron deficiency anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Since vitamin D crosses the placenta, most newborns have adequate levels at birth. Furthermore, vitamin D deficiency would usually remain asymptomatic unless it led to rickets, which is not a life-threatening condition and not common in industrialized nations. However, as the amount of vitamin D in breastmilk is usually not sufficient to meet infants' daily requirements, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in exclusively and partially breastfed infants starting within the first few days of birth.

C) CORRECT:

Vitamin K levels are low in all newborns because very little crosses the placental barrier, and its concentration in breast milk is insignificant. In addition, newborns have sterile intestines, and the establishment of gut microflora that synthesizes vitamin K takes approximately 6 months. As vitamin K is necessary for the production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X, not supplementing it within a few hours after birth can enable a potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Another risk factor for vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn is prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Key learning point: All newborns should receive vitamin K supplementation at birth to prevent potentially fatal hemorrhagic disease due to low stores and immature gut flora.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B1 (thiamine), like all water-soluble vitamins, crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk. Infants born to thiamine-deficient mothers can develop infantile beriberi, which, if untreated, can be life-threatening. However, thiamine deficiency usually occurs in countries where the main diet is composed of polished white rice or as a result of chronic alcohol abuse.

E) INCORRECT:

Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin that crosses the placenta and is present in breast milk, making postnatal supplementation for the infant unnecessary.

To prevent neural tube defects and support maternal nutrient needs, folic acid supplementation in individuals planning pregnancy should start at least 3 months before conception and continue throughout pregnancy. After birth, breastfeeding individuals should keep taking a daily multivitamin with folic acid to meet increased nutritional demands and ensure adequate folate levels in breast milk. Therefore, folic acid supplementation is indicated for the mother, not the child.
questions.hint: This vitamin is used in gamma-carboxylation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder presents to the ED with confusion and unsteady gait. His family reports poor nutrition and frequent binge drinking. Vital signs are BP, 112/70 mm Hg; P, 102; R, 20; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). On exam, he has horizontal nystagmus and ataxia. Laboratory values are notable for hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL, sodium 139 mEq/L, glucose 86 mg/dL. Which vitamin deficiency best explains his current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neuropathy, paresthesias, and megaloblastic anemia, but it does not cause oculomotor dysfunction or confusion.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This presentation is classic for Wernicke encephalopathy, caused by thiamine deficiency. The triad of confusion, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction is highly suggestive. Chronic alcohol use and poor nutrition are major risk factors, and thiamine repletion is urgently indicated in the ED to prevent progression to irreversible Korsakoff syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency typically causes osteomalacia in adults, presenting with bone pain, pathologic fractures, or myopathy. It is not associated with acute neurologic changes such as confusion and nystagmus.

D) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Although confusion may be present, the absence of dermatitis and diarrhea makes this less consistent with the patient's presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with gingival bleeding, poor wound healing, and petechiae. It does not cause acute oculomotor dysfunction, ataxia, or confusion, which are central to this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the clinic because of bleeding gums, fatigue, and joint pain for the past three weeks. He is currently unemployed and has been living in a homeless shelter for the past two months. His diet consists mainly of bread and instant noodles; he rarely consumes fruits or vegetables. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. The patient appears thin and pale. BMI is 17.3 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Physical examination shows brittle, coiled hair. There are scattered ecchymoses and petechiae over his lower extremities. His gums are swollen and bleed easily with gentle probing. There is mild tenderness in his knees and ankles, but no joint swelling or erythema. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is a congenital bleeding disorder characterized by mucocutaneous bleeding (e.g., bleeding gums, easy bruising) that typically manifests in childhood. vWD does not cause coiled hair or swollen gums.

B) CORRECT:

Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency. Classic features include fatigue, swollen and bleeding gums, poor wound healing, arthralgia, and characteristic skin findings (e.g., perifollicular hemorrhages, petechiae, ecchymoses, coiled hair). Risk factors include insufficient dietary intake of fruits and vegetables and alcohol use disorder. Scurvy should be considered in individuals with risk factors for poor nutritional intake (e.g., homelessness) who present with typical clinical features. Measurement of plasma or leukocyte vitamin C levels establishes the diagnosis. Treatment for scurvy is vitamin C supplementation.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) can manifest with fatigue, petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal bleeding. However, AML does not cause coiled hair or arthralgia and most commonly occurs in older individuals. Moreover, additional findings such as recurrent infections, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly would be expected in a patient with AML.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis can manifest with coagulopathy, easy bruising, and mucosal bleeding and can be caused by chronic alcohol use disorder. However, liver cirrhosis does not cause coiled hair, swollen gums, or arthralgia. Furthermore, additional dermal (e.g., pruritus, jaundice, palmar erythema, telangiectasia) and abdominal (e.g., hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites) features, as well as features such as asterixis and Dupuytren contracture, would be expected in a patient with cirrhosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) typically manifests with petechiae, ecchymoses, and mucosal bleeding due to low platelet count as a result of immune destruction. However, ITP is not associated with swollen gums, coiled hair, or arthralgia.
questions.hint: This condition is caused by a nutritional deficiency, which leads to impaired collagen synthesis and fragile connective tissue.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of progressive weakness and numbness in his lower extremities. He also reports difficulty walking and occasional blurred vision. His medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. He used to work as an accountant but lost his job 8 months ago. His diet has primarily consisted of white rice for the past 6 months due to socioeconomic hardship. His only medication is metformin, which he has been taking inconsistently for the past 8 months. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He appears thin and malnourished. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows bilateral foot drop, diminished sensation to light touch and pinprick in his hands and feet, and absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. Cranial nerve examination shows horizontal nystagmus. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) can manifest with progressive, symmetrical, ascending weakness and areflexia but typically follows a recent infection and does not manifest with nystagmus. Therefore, an alternative diagnosis is more likely.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's progressive symmetrical peripheral neuropathy (sensory and motor) and horizontal nystagmus, combined with his dietary history, strongly suggest thiamine deficiency. Chronic thiamine deficiency results in dry beriberi (characterized by symmetrical peripheral neuropathy and progressive muscle wasting) and Wernicke encephalopathy (characterized by confusion, oculomotor dysfunction with nystagmus, and gait ataxia). Some patients may also develop features of wet beriberi (e.g., high-output cardiac failure). Risk factors for thiamine deficiency include malnutrition, malabsorption, and heavy drinking. Thiamine replacement is essential to prevent irreversible neurological damage.

C) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) can manifest with progressive weakness in the lower extremities. However, this patient presents with sensory loss, areflexia, and nystagmus, which are not features of ALS.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can manifest with neurological deficits and nystagmus, but typically affects young adults. Additionally, episodes of neurological deficits in MS are separated in time and space, but this patient has chronic, progressive, symmetrical, ascending peripheral neuropathy with areflexia, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic neuropathy can manifest with symmetrical, distal sensorimotor polyneuropathy, but nystagmus is not a typical feature of this condition. This patient's dietary history and malnutrition make an alternative diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's neurological examination shows findings of both peripheral and central nervous system involvement.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of prolonged stiffness in the morning and progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands over the past 4 months. Examination shows bilateral swelling and mild tenderness of the wrists and the second, third, and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints. Her range of motion is limited by pain. Serum studies show elevated anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Treatment with methotrexate is begun. At a follow-up examination, her serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) concentration is 75 U/L and her serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) concentration is 81 U/L. Which of the following substances is essential for the function of these enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin (vitamin B3) is a precursor to NAD+ and NADP+, which function as cofactors in redox reactions. Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra and glossitis. However, neither niacin nor its derivatives are required for transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiamine pyrophosphate, the active form of thiamine (vitamin B1), serves as a cofactor for several enzymes of carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. Thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and Beriberi. However, it is not involved in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

C) INCORRECT:

Biotin (vitamin B7) is a cofactor for various carboxylation enzymes, including acetyl-CoA carboxylase, methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase. Biotin deficiency can cause dermatitis, enteritis, and alopecia. However, it is not involved in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

D) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is a cofactor in hydroxylation and redox reactions. Importantly, it serves as a coenzyme to lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase, which are essential to collagen synthesis. However, it is not required for transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetrahydrofolate, the active form of folic acid (vitamin B9), is a cofactor for methylation reactions such as those essential to nucleic acid synthesis. Folic acid deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia and, in the case of maternal deficiency, in neural tube defects. However, it is not required for the transamination reactions performed by AST and ALT.

F) INCORRECT:

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is a precursor to flavin mononucleotide and flavin adenine dinucleotide, which serve as cofactors for numerous enzymes (e.g., acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, glutathione reductase). Riboflavin deficiency can cause cheilosis and conjunctivitis with corneal vascularization. However, vitamin B2 derivatives do not participate in transamination reactions such as those performed by AST and ALT.

G) CORRECT:

Pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of pyridoxine (vitamin B6), is an important cofactor in the transamination reactions performed by AST and ALT. Moreover, it is required for glycogen phosphorylase reactions, decarboxylation, and synthesis of cystathionine, heme, niacin, and histamine, as well as several neurotransmitters.

Methotrexate is the disease-modifying antirheumatic drug of choice for patients diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and may cause minor transaminitis or, in rare cases, severe drug-induced liver injury.
questions.hint: Aminotransferases catalyze transamination reactions, in which the amino group of one amino acid is transferred to an α-ketoacid, forming an amino acid. Deficiency of the cofactor required for transaminations is associated with irritability, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia.
